March 21, 1901.

INTERNATIONAL EPISODE.

HE most casual observer of the map of
TSwitzerland
will have noticed that the
southern boundaries are extremely irregular.
Zigzag lines caused by mountains and valleys
and singular political divisions make the plan
of that country to droop like a tattered fringe
over the northern edge of Italy. It was in
connection with these topographical peculiarities that I met with some adventures.
We had started out on bicycles to go from
the sunny town of Lugano to another Swiss
town equally beautiful and equally Italian, to
Locarno on Lake Maggoire. The ride was delightful, and we proceeded with due enjoyment
of our surroundings, and in possession of passports and all necessary papers until we came
to the frontier hamlet of Fortessa. It was
easy to pass the Swiss custom house because
we were going out, but it was not many moments before we realized that we were in a foreign country, for we were immediately halted
by another set of guards in uniform, who inspected our papers and looked critically upon
our persons. It never occurred to me that the
few hours that we should be in Italy we
should be under suspicion, but the Italian custom house wished to know where we were going. That was easily explained, but there
were possibilities in the thing. We might turn
off at the next crossing, flee to the woods and
sell those bicycles, escaping the tax.
There were various ways in which this matter might have been settled. We might have
been imprisoned and held until we were ready
to go back into Switzerland by the way we
came, or, we might have been obliged to pay a
tariff duty about equal to the value of the machines, but the Italian government chose another way. It was delicately considerate and
complimentary. We were conducted across the
country under military escort. To be sure this
escort consisted of one soldier who had no gun
nor yet a bicycle. My better half mounted her

No. 11

wheel and rode, but to allay suspicion, and to
'avoid the used of any weapons he might have
concealed in his clothing, I walked, as far as
Luino, over two or three miles of the
most aggravatingly smooth roads imaginable
down through the city to the chief custom
house, paid an insignificant sum for the
examination of our papers and the services
of our soldier, then passed on to the steamboat landing where we put the padlock on the
wheels and left them in charge of the guard.
Poor fellow! After all that walk he had to stay
there two hours more, pass his supper time,
while we walked about, saw the town and fared
sumptuously. In fact, he followed the wheels
on board the steamer, remained with us until
we had passed an invisible frontier, and delivered us once more in the hands of the
Swiss.
I need not relate the details of the journey
we took returning by a route entirely within
Swiss territory to Laganio. Suffice it to say
that we soon after started southward for Como
with the expectation of staying a few days on
the Italian lakes and returning to Switzerland.
For some reason I received the impression that
the Italian custom house on that route would
offer no difficulties. I found my mistake at
Chiasso. We had been coming slowly down
the road, enjoying the landscape; and photographing the peasants, with no suspicion that
bicycles were an object of terror to Italian officials. As usual, we carried very little money
on the road, and were unprepared to pay taxes
or to buy official courtesy. To my dismay the
Philistines at Chiasso demanded ninety francs
apiece for the passage of our machines. The
most profound search revealed only half that
sum on the combined persons of the party. In
letters of credit they were not learned, and so
small a town could not pretend to have a bank.
The nearest financial resource was at Como,
two miles away. Things looked dubious for a
time, but at last a brilliant thought flashed
over me. I deposited my wife and one machine

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

with the custom house, and road the other to
Como after the money. In an hour and a half
I returned withe plenty of funds to claim my
deposits. My active pledge had in the meanwhile employed her time with usury, for her
water color brush had been capturing a small
Italian citizen in red cap and bare feet. By
the time the papers were made out "Miguel"
was fast in her sketch-book.
If Lake Como had not been so often described, I might relate my impressions. These
little difficulties with human institutions made
no difference in the beauty of the scenery, but
I would not have you think that my adventures with the custom house ceased at this
point.
The journey from Como to Chiavenna can
be made by rail, but we did not propose to
travel in that manner, neither did we intend to
make the trip in the ordinary way by water,
but mounted our wheels, and started up the
western side of the western arm of the lake.
Lake Como would be better described by the
use of the word "leg," for on the map it looks
like an overgrown horse-raddish root on the
run, the city of Como being fastened to the
" toe of the forward foot. We followed the
road as far as the little town of Torriggia.
Here the highway suddenly dwindled to a
mule path, and we sat down under the trees to
rest, to photograph and sketch until the next
steamer came by. This arrived in the course
of an hour or two and we led our horses on
board. As we mounted the steps of the upper
deck we suddenly became conscious of friendly
faces. First one and then the other came forward, until there were four young men from
Baltimore before us. Not only that, but they
were all from my department of the University,
and persons with whom I had been in daily
association for years. You will excuse me if
I say this word "paralyzed" to express our
emotions, for at Bellaggio we changed the
steamer for a row boat and had ourselves propelled to the north side of the lake. From
that point we went up toward the passes of the
Alps by man power, furnished by members of
the party.
It was up in the pass above Chiavenna that
the closing events of this episode took place.

We had pushed rapidly up the hill in order to
reach the Swiss border at the proper time, and
full of haste and brown dust, I presented my
papers, receipts and passports. The official
was very polite. The papers were all clear
that I had deposited money, and that I was the
person. Very sorry, however, that he had no
authorization to /Say out money. Papers failed
to indicate at what point the bicycles were to
be exported. I had in fact told the people at
Chiasso a dozen times over that I was going
out by the way of Chiavenna, but they had
neglected the proper formalities. It would be
necessary to request the Italian government in
Rome to permit the custom house at Villa di
Chiavenna to return me the duty on two bicycles. The thing looked for a moment like robbery, but I was comforted with the assurance
that within two weeks the same thing had happened to eleven other Americans and that they
had come out all right.
It was Friday, and we were in the uttermost
parts of the kingdom. A petition by letter
meant a week or more of delay. So armed
with a properly worded telegram I hastened
back a mile down the hill to the shoemaker
who kept the post and telegraph office, and
turned over my affairs to the minions of electricity. In the meanwhile, we made ourselves
comfortable on the Swiss side of the line. It
was a village of at least seven houses, and in
the midst of chestnut trees, and side hill farming, performed by the female population. For
two whole days we studied Swiss institutions,
painted the scenery and collected botanical
specimens.
At five o'clock Saturday evening a reply,
dated at Rome at 12 the same day reached the
custom house at Villa di Chiavenna, and our
financial matters were straightened out.
I have never obtained a really satisfactory
history of that message. One does not like to
criticize unduly the methods of foreign governments when there may be great natural
difficulties to overcome. Especially is it true
in this case, where anyone can see from the
maps that Villa di Chianna is 2500 feet above
the sea, and the wire from Rome comes all the
way up hill.
JOHN MARTIN VINCENT.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
APELLO.
Mr. Editor.
It occured to me the other day that the great
use of a Junior in College is to advise Freshmen: and since I am debarred in future, from
giving Freshmen any more physical advice,
I am going to excercise my other prerogatives,
and give them some mental and moral advice
concerning a matter which I think should be
brought to their attention.
I wonder, to how many Freshman, has the
fact presented itself that they owe the University something more than their tuition fees?
You applaud the leaders of your class, the
members of the athletic teams, and,sometimes
the musical clubs. Do you ever try to do the
things they do? You cannot, you say. How
do you know you cannot? Have you tried?
If you are musical or shine in the social world,
join the musical clubs. If you are big and
strong, patronize "Mac" and the cage. If
you are studious, try for class honors. If you
are none of the above, but have a sneaking
fondness for Dr. Green's papers, try for the
NEWS-LETTER staff.
It is to this last class of men that I address
this appeal. It is your duty to help the paper,
because if you can write, your work is needed
in its columns. If the paper is not as good as
it might be (I am sure the editors will pardon
me) try and make it better. Criticism is good
but work is better. How can the editors ever
improve the NEWS-LETTER when everyone
abuses it, and no one writes for it? Don't be
like the basement-loafers who look at their
copies on alternate Thursday evenings, and
then always say "Well, it's a pretty bum
number. I don't see why we can't have a
good paper here." I asked one of these gentlemen one day if he had even done anything
to make it better, and he said "Oh, I sent in a
piece once, but they would'nt take it." I
discovered afterward that the piece in question
was something on the order of Baccaccio's
famous tales—naughty but very nice.
Now, boys, that is not the way to support
your college paper. The NEWS-LETTER represents the literary ability of the Hopkins undergraduate body. To the world at large we are

3

known by this paper. If we think it is poor,
we should make it better. If you think you
can write, try for the staff. If you don't make
it, write for the paper anyhow. If you have
,no literary ability, don't attempt to criticise
those who have. I know you are going to say
"Yes, that's true" and then do nothing. I did
the same thing. I am sorry now, and I am
doing penance by trying to keep you from my
error. There are places on the staff, fill them.
Show the rest of the world that the Hopkins
men are not all ignorant, and,show the rest of
the Hopkins men that the class of 1903 is alive to
its responsibilities. Don't wait 'till next year.
It will be too late then. Try now, and then
next year you will thank him who now gives
you this advice.

A JUNIOR.
GLORY BE UNTO HIM!
(Mr. W B. Swindell of the Senior class of the Johns Hopkins
University Is engaged to be married to a young lady of Boston,
Mass.—The Baltimore Sun.)

he's going to leave us! No longer
ALAS,
will his stentorian voice ring out in commanding tones urging a re-awakening of sleeping enthusiasts, no longer will the halls of
McCoy resound with his glorious voice, no
longer will the instructor in a political science
be compelled to outvoice the voice of him in
the holy corner. Yes he's going to leave us.
He who is the J. H. U., he who is everybody,
he who alone can command the bands of Hopkins, he—HE—HE is going to leave us. Weep,
ye legions weep. The attractions of the North
are too strong for this Southern son of valor,
he must go; even the baton of general is small
compared to the northern attraction. He has
laughed with us, he has fought with us, he has
lead us, he has spinached to us, and now he
will no longer give pleasure unto himself thus.
The future was bright before him. The
portals of a great institution were open to him.
Group III, with variations, lead anywhere: it
has lead to bliss for him. Happiness be with
him; and may he be blessed with many joys.
Success and glory be unto him who is

Athletic Editors,

(1

column of this issue we publish
IN"another
Billy" Maddren's letter of resignation
from his position as President of •the Athletic
Board. The "NEWS-LETTER" joins with the
student body in expressing its regret at the
loss from active leadership of one who has
been so conspicuous in athletic circles during
the past three years.
With the exception of Director Mackdermott, no one connected with the University is
more thoroughly alive to our athletic interests,
nor more completely conversant with every
branch of Hopkins sport than Mr. Maddren ;
while together with these qualities he combines
executive ability, and the faculty for imparting enthusiasm among the student ranks.
While Mr. Maddren has retired from his official position, we hope that we may still have
the benefit of his advice in athletic matters.
In choosing his successor we consider that
the Board has exercised great discernment.
Mr. Reese is one who has the athletic interests
of the University at heart, and anything he
undertakes is certain of a successful termination. Besides this he may rely upon the cooperation of the students.
or w
The successes of the Track and Field Team
in the recent indoor meets in this city and
Washington show plainly that despite our
heavy losses of last year Hopkins still has a
team which comes up to the high standard set

by the champions of 190o. Some of the best
men in the dashes and runs left the University,
but those remaining form a nucleus on which
at the beginning of this year Director Mackdermott started to build. The material in the
Freshman class was good, and under hard
training soon developed some excellent men in
the dashes, so that the first meet brought many
prizes to the trophy-room. The team has been
showing up stronger at every succeeding meet,
and deserves the heartiest congratulations of
all Hopkins men for its zealous efforts. Though
it is composed of men from all branches of the
University, there are enough younger men on
the team to assure a firm foundation for next
year.
or w
In our last issue we called attention to the
duty now confronting us regarding the necessary improvements to be added to American
League Park, for the benefit of Hopkins Athletes. No matter what bright joys the future
holds in store for us, in the shape of expensive
athletic fields and green campuses, our present
needs are pressing. The musical :clubs have
generously enlisted themselves in the service
of raising the finances needed for this purpose,
and will shortly give a concert for tha benefit
of the athletic fund. It is gratifying to see
how the students have responded to the subscription call, and, judging from results thus
obtained, we predict that they can be counted
upon to turn out in a body the evening of the
concert. Despite our lack of students, our
athletic victories during the last few years
have placed Hopkins upon a higher footing in
the athletic world, and this fact together with
bright prospects for the future should stimulate
us all to greater activity.

HE readers of this issue should mark well
and inwardly digest a communication in
these columns headed "Apello," and signed
"A Junior". The moral of the epistle is
pointed at the members of the Class of 1903,
but there is no reason why the rest of the
University should not profit by the excellent
advice contained therein. It is broad enough
to embrace all classes, but, doubtless the reason

T

THE NEWS-LETTER.
for especially admonishing the Freshmen is
because it is usually considered that their juvenile buoyancy is still in the effervescent
stage, and that their characters have not yet
been moulded into permanent form. In
by-gone days the "NEWS—LETTER" has harped
upon the theme of a man's duty to his college;
in days to come it will doubtless continue to sing
this lay, but a letter like "Apello" coming as
it does from one not officially connected with
this paper, carries with it more weight than
anything we may say upon the subject. Besides it is an encouraging sign, for it shows
that the work of "by gone days" is finally
bearing fruit.
iv or er
A gratifying recognition of the worth of the
University has just been witnessed.
The German American citizens of Baltimore
propose to contribute $100,000 towards the
endowment fund of a million now being raised.
This contribution is to establish a chair of
German language and literature.
It is reported that $20,000 of the amount
has already been raised by fifteen gentlemen
who are members of the Germania Club. We
take pleasure in voicing the sentiment of gratitude which every Hopkins man must feel towards these liberal-minded gentlemen. Such
generosity should, and doubtless will,serve as
an object lesson to other beneficently inclined
citizens of Baltimore.

THE HOPKINS CLUB.
IT is reported that the Johns Hopkins Club
may soon move to other quarters. The growing attractiveness and interest would seem to
demand a site more easily reached by the
members. The Club boasts of an excellent
kitchen and buffet, which may be enjoyed at
very moderate rates; but the members do not
lunch or spend their evenings at the club as
much as they might, were the position nearer
the University, or on their way from places
of amusement. Great atttactions too are
offered to members who wish to occupy rooms
in the club house. It is felt that this and the
other good features of the Club will be enhanced by a more central location.

THE FRESHMAN BANQUET.
Freshman banquet, marking as it does
THE
the cessation of friendly clashes between
naughty two and naughty three, was a howling
Success from several standpoints. Almost every
member of the clsss attended, the apt speeches
were well delivered, and the presence of two
Juniors during the festivities added a certain
fascination to the pleasure, and without doubt,
made the affair the most unique in the annals
of similar feeds. The class of 1903 is the first
to enjoy the distinction of having entertained
such unheard of guests at its Freshmen banquet; and it is greatly to the credit of naughty
three that at no time during the evening was
a spirit of animosity exhibited. Songs were
sung, toasts were responded to, and frequent
knocks made at the Juniors, but at no time
were any attempts made to belittle or discomfort the unexpected guests. Before the last
course had been served the aforementioned
gentlemen were invited to partake of Freshman
hospitality. They accordingiy drew up, and
the mellowing influences of the spread soon
had their effects. Both guests made very appropriate speeches, and assured their entertainers that, with the exception of 1902, naughtythree is the best class that ever entered Hopkins. They ended by expressing sincere apapreciation for the hospitality accorded them.
As a toastmaster, Harry K. Tootle proved
to be the real thing. He was full of catchy
jokes, and always had some bright remark
to continue the merriment. His address in
which he referred to "taking the Law into
our hands" was greeted with deafening applause. The toast "Our Newly-Acquired
Possessions" was construed by some to refer
to the Juniors present, instead of Homewood.
Accordingly, some very good puns were gotten
off by impromptu speakers. The jolly time
ended with numerous class yells and songs,
interspersed with several rousing "Hullabaloos." The menu cards were bound in the
University colors with "class '03, J. H. U."
engraved in olive and white on the cover page.
Messrs. Robinson C. Pagon, Benjamin Weeks,
R. Curzon Hoffman, Wethered L. Lilly, and

MUSICAL CLUBS.
Johns Hopkins Glee, Banjo and ManHE
dolin Clubs gave an informal concert at
the University Club on the evening of Friday,
March Eighth. This is the first time that the
Clubs have appeared before the public in the
guise of a paid orchestra, and the result was
not altogether successful. The audience did
not deem it necessary to stop talking during
the songs and other pieces, consequently it
was hard for the men to play and sing, and
still harder for those who were appreciative to
hear the music. Altogether the evening was
not enjoyable or successful, and it is to be
hoped that no more such concerts will be
scheduled.
After a few attempts by the various Clubs
to make themselves heard, the men gave up,
and mingled with the crowd in its rush for
refreshments. Then the pleasanter part of the
evening began, for there were a number of
attractive girls and women present, and several
Johns Hopkins Professors and Alumni very
thoughtfully looked after the welfare of the
men.
Manager Bird has nearly completed his
arrangements for the Easter trip, and from
present prospects it will be as thoroughly successful as the one last year. So far the plans
are to leave Baltimore Friday afternoon ou one
of the Bay Line Steamers and give the first
concert at Old Point Comfort on Saturday
night. This is the very best night in the

whole year to attract an audience, and it was
only through the energy and perseverance of
the manager that this date was obtained. Last
year the Clubs had to play second best, and
give their concert on Good-Friday when there
were necessarily fewer people present. But
this year Princeton will have to take our last
year's place while the Hopkins Clubs have the
best night.
From Old Point Comfort the men will go to
Richmond and give a concert there on the following Monday—These places are the only
ones that are definitely decided upon, but it is
likely that several other cities will be visited
before the Clubs return. There is even a rumor that Atlantic City will be "taken in,"
but this is a little doubtful.

T

THE SECOND BALTIMORE CONCERT.
most important concert in the history
THE
of the Johns Hopkins Musical Clubs will
be given in McCoy Hall on Tuesday evening,
March 26. Its great importance lies in the
fact that the proceeds will be used to help pay
for the erection of the club house and gymnasium on the new athletic grounds.
The alumni of the University have been doing their utmost to raise the necessary million
dollar endowment fund, and it would surely
seem rather ungrateful in the undergraduates
if they do not heartily support this concert,
and thus take away the additional responsibility of paying for the club house.
From the manner in which the subscription
lists have been received, however, it is unlikely that the former Hopkins men will have any
reason to believe that they are the only ones
interested in the welfare of their Alma Mater.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

"BILLY" MADDREN RESIGNS.

THE HOPKINS GAMES.

AT a meeting of the Athletic Board, held
Tuesday evening, March 12th, President
"Billy" Maddren handed in the 'following
letter of resignation:

Carnival of Sports under the auspices
THE
of the Athletic Association of the Johns

To the Board of Directors of the 7ohns Hopkins
Athletic Association:
GENTLEMEN,—It is with great regret that I
am obliged to tender my resignation as President of the Johns Hopkins Athletic Association. My reasons are that I am unable to
give sufficient time to athletic affairs because
of my studies. This resignation is to take
effect upon the election of my successor, and
not later than March i5th. Yours truly,
WILLIAM HARVEY MADDREN.
Every effort was used by the Board to dissuade Mr. Maddren from his course, but he
explained that it would be impossible for him
to devote sufficient time to the duties of presidency, as his studies at the Medical school for
the remainder of the year would require hard
work and close confinement. With great
reluctancy the board accepted the resignation,
and appointed a committee, with Dr. Renouf
as chairman, to draw up an appropriate resolution in appreciation of Mr. Maddren's work
in behalf of Hopkins Athletics. It is safe to
say, that during the past three years .no other
student of the University has instilled as much
life into athletics at Hopkins, as has "Billy
Maddren." His most conspicuous work has
been in Lacrosse, and it is largely owing to his
efforts that three championship banners, 1898,
1899, 1900, now adorn the walls of the trophy
room but besides this his advice in athletic
matters has been of the greatest benefit, and all
regret his retirement from active athletics.
Mr. Albert Reese was unanimously elected
by the Board to fill the position of president.
Mr, Reese is one of the few alumni who has
not allowed his interest in J. H. U. sports to
stop when he received his degree, but has, on
the other hand, worked faithfully to advance
them. This interest in athletics and his executive ability make him the most suitable man
who could have been chosen for the position.

Hopkins University was held on last Saturday night at the Fifth Regiment Armory.
Athletes from diverse parts of the city and
state were entertained by the University men,
who gave them a good run for their money.
These are the first indoor games that the
University has given for some years past, and
that they were a success is the verdict of everyone. Surely there were some hitches, but, for
the most part, the events were run off in good
time by the clerk of the course, Wm. M.
Mackdermott, to whom all credit is due for the
success of the meet.
The hall had been very attractively decorated, and when the call was sounded for the
first event at 8.10, the seats lining the walls
around the floor space of the Armory were
comfortably filled with fair enthusiasts who
had come out in goodly numbers to cheer their
especial favorites on to victory, while the gallery was filled with "rooters" of the various
organizations who had occupied themselves
with shouting encouragement to their teams.
A large share of the honors came to the
wearers of the Black and Blue, but the representatives of Marston's University School and
the Boys' Latin School also came in for a
goodly share of the prizes.
There was a slight delay in the starting of
the game owing to the late arrival of several
of the officials; but when the games were once
started they went ahead at a pleasing pace. The
program was a very attractive one, being much
less unwieldy than the ordinary program of
Baltimore meets. Foot races were the predominant features, while there were only three
field events.
The first event—the interscholastic 40 yard
dash—was easily won by G. C. Gantz, of the
Boys' Latin School, with Bayless and Cloud
close on him for second and third honors.
E. L. Pessagno ran a beautiful race in the
40 yard open handicap, winning first place, but
was closely pressed by Tootle, who won the
40 yard dash in the Baltimore Athletic games

THE NEWS-LETTER.

8

of several weeks ago. Perhaps the races which
interested the majority of the spectators were
the twelve relay races. In the first, Marston's
easily defeated the Emerson Institute team, of
Washington. The Boys' Latin School team
also ran a pretty race against Deichmann's.
The special invitation relay race between St.
John's College and Johns Hopkins University
was one of the prettiest of the evening. The
first two contestants, Whitman and Garey, ran
almost a dead heat till the last lap, when Whitman passed his rival and finished a few yards
ahead of him. Unfortunately for St. John's,
Wells was not able to hold his ground on the
next lap, and when Riggs took up the work
where England and Hoffman had left off,
Hopkins had a lead of half a lap, and Riggs
was able to hold his lead without exertion.
Mullen, who ran under the auspices of the
Johns Hopkins Club, was the only scratch man
in the mile run. He pushed ahead of all his
opponents, and caught up with Heiner, who
was leading. On the last lap Mullens purted,
and easily won by io yards.
In the 440 yard dash, Riggs ran a beautiful
race. On each lap he gradually pushed up
past his opponents, and won handily on the last
lap by a beautiful spurt. All the other events,
too, were of equal interest, but perhaps the
most amusing of the whole evening was the
potato race, won by C. F. Edwards. Garret
won first in the 16-lb. shot, and second in the
high jump. In the 88o yard, novice, England
was the victor.

AMONG THE COLLEGES.

BALL TEAM?

athletic department of the University
THE
of Chicago has started the policy of giving the University "C" to winners of indoor
meets,
ww
The candidates for Yale's track team are
showing up strong in the field events, but not
so well in the runs. There are 130 men in the
field.

SINCE"Robbie"and his small band of baseball enthusiasts have been practicing in the
cage here of late, considerable interest has
been shown in a base-ball team for Hopkins.
There seems to have been for some time past
a sort of half-hearted movement on foot to get
the consent of the Athletic Association for a
team. Such a movement will undoubtedly
meet with serious opposition, on account of the
deplorable manner in which last year's team
was managed, and its untimely end. Yet, if
the supporters of this new movement show
enough earnestness to warrant it, and will
guarantee a team which will practice, and stand
by the University during the entire season,
there can be no doubt but that the Athletic
Association will give such a team its hearty
support.
Several challenges have been received from
prominent colleges and associations, and it
seems rather sad, that we energetic Hopkinsonions who are making such rapid strides in
other lines of athletic sport, cannot organize
and support a base-ball team. Probably the
main handicap to last year's attempt was the
lack of grounds out of doors, on which to
practice. Such is not the case this year, as we
have new grounds specially adapted to baseball, at a moderate distance from the University.
If the men who are interested in this project
mean business, and have any hope of organizing a team, it is high time that the movement were being pushed as is is getting late in
the season. We have made a "rep for Hopkins in Football, Lacrosse, Track and Field.
Then with good material, and men who are
anxious and ready to make it a success, why
can we not have a base-ball team.

The course of lectures this year on the
Turnbull Lectureship foundation will be given
by Hamilton W. Mabie, Litt. D., editor of
"The Outlook," and author of several literary
works. The subject of the course will be
"Poetry in America." The lectures will be
given in McCoy Hall, at 5 o'clock, beginning
Tuesday, April 16th; they will begin punctually and will close within the hour. The door
will be closed when the lecturer rises.
Jab .a6
At their last monthly meeting, the Trustees
did not discuss the presidency of the University or the proposed endowment fund. A letter from Mr. Henry 0. Thompson, Treasurer
of the Alumni Association, presented the University p000 as the nucleus of a fund for the
establishment of an alumni scholarship. The
gift was accepted with thanks..
The trustees designated the professorship
founded some time ago by Dr. Henry Willis
Baxley as the Baxley Professorship of Pathology. They voted their thanks to Mr. Henry
Sonneborn and Mr. Jesse Tyson for recent
gifts to the University.

Dr. John Dewey, Hopkins Fellow in '83, and
Ph. D. '84, who is at present Professor of Philosophy in the University of Chicago, has been
appointed the head of the Chicago University
High School. This school is to be result of
the consolidation of the Chicago Institute with
the University of Chicago.
sr or or
Professor James Schouler, LL. D., of Boston, author of a "History of the United States
under the Constitution," will deliver four biographical lectures in continuation of his
course begun last year, on the great founders
of the American Republic. The lectures will
be given in the Donovan Room, McCoy Hall,
at 5 p. m., on March 20, 22, 27, and 30.
w or or
Professor John Bassett Moore, LL. D., of
Columbia University, formerly Assistant Secretary of State and later Secretary to the Peace
Commission at Paris, will deliver two lectures
on international questions,—"Our Treaty with
Spain," and "Our Policy in the Far East."—
The lectures will be given in McCoy Hall, at
5 p. m., on March 19th and 21st.

The Senior—Junior debate is to take place
at 8 o'clock to-night in McCoy Hall.
The chairman of the committee of arrangements is Mr. Harry S. Bryne, who is president
of the Senate. Mr. A. W. Bruton will be chief
usher, Mr. Aubrey Pearre chairman of the
committee on invitations, and Mr. Norman
Boyer chairman of the press committee. The
arrangements committee has decided to limit
admission to the debate to those who have
tickets. These tickets may be obtained from
members of the Committee.
The Musical Clubs will take part in the exercises.
The Freshmen who will declaim for the Lee
prize at the same time, are Plaggemeyer, Blum,
and Zimmerman.

reunion and banquet Friday of last week at
the Johns Hopkins Club. Dr. Thomas R.
Brown presided. City Councilman George
Stewart Brown, whose exchange of compliments with the Mayor is still talked of, responded to the toast, "My friend Mr. Hayes."

March 21, 1901.

INTERNATIONAL EPISODE.

HE most casual observer of the map of
TSwitzerland
will have noticed that the
southern boundaries are extremely irregular.
Zigzag lines caused by mountains and valleys
and singular political divisions make the plan
of that country to droop like a tattered fringe
over the northern edge of Italy. It was in
connection with these topographical peculiarities that I met with some adventures.
We had started out on bicycles to go from
the sunny town of Lugano to another Swiss
town equally beautiful and equally Italian, to
Locarno on Lake Maggoire. The ride was delightful, and we proceeded with due enjoyment
of our surroundings, and in possession of passports and all necessary papers until we came
to the frontier hamlet of Fortessa. It was
easy to pass the Swiss custom house because
we were going out, but it was not many moments before we realized that we were in a foreign country, for we were immediately halted
by another set of guards in uniform, who inspected our papers and looked critically upon
our persons. It never occurred to me that the
few hours that we should be in Italy we
should be under suspicion, but the Italian custom house wished to know where we were going. That was easily explained, but there
were possibilities in the thing. We might turn
off at the next crossing, flee to the woods and
sell those bicycles, escaping the tax.
There were various ways in which this matter might have been settled. We might have
been imprisoned and held until we were ready
to go back into Switzerland by the way we
came, or, we might have been obliged to pay a
tariff duty about equal to the value of the machines, but the Italian government chose another way. It was delicately considerate and
complimentary. We were conducted across the
country under military escort. To be sure this
escort consisted of one soldier who had no gun
nor yet a bicycle. My better half mounted her

No. 11

wheel and rode, but to allay suspicion, and to
'avoid the used of any weapons he might have
concealed in his clothing, I walked, as far as
Luino, over two or three miles of the
most aggravatingly smooth roads imaginable
down through the city to the chief custom
house, paid an insignificant sum for the
examination of our papers and the services
of our soldier, then passed on to the steamboat landing where we put the padlock on the
wheels and left them in charge of the guard.
Poor fellow! After all that walk he had to stay
there two hours more, pass his supper time,
while we walked about, saw the town and fared
sumptuously. In fact, he followed the wheels
on board the steamer, remained with us until
we had passed an invisible frontier, and delivered us once more in the hands of the
Swiss.
I need not relate the details of the journey
we took returning by a route entirely within
Swiss territory to Laganio. Suffice it to say
that we soon after started southward for Como
with the expectation of staying a few days on
the Italian lakes and returning to Switzerland.
For some reason I received the impression that
the Italian custom house on that route would
offer no difficulties. I found my mistake at
Chiasso. We had been coming slowly down
the road, enjoying the landscape; and photographing the peasants, with no suspicion that
bicycles were an object of terror to Italian officials. As usual, we carried very little money
on the road, and were unprepared to pay taxes
or to buy official courtesy. To my dismay the
Philistines at Chiasso demanded ninety francs
apiece for the passage of our machines. The
most profound search revealed only half that
sum on the combined persons of the party. In
letters of credit they were not learned, and so
small a town could not pretend to have a bank.
The nearest financial resource was at Como,
two miles away. Things looked dubious for a
time, but at last a brilliant thought flashed
over me. I deposited my wife and one machine

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

with the custom house, and road the other to
Como after the money. In an hour and a half
I returned withe plenty of funds to claim my
deposits. My active pledge had in the meanwhile employed her time with usury, for her
water color brush had been capturing a small
Italian citizen in red cap and bare feet. By
the time the papers were made out "Miguel"
was fast in her sketch-book.
If Lake Como had not been so often described, I might relate my impressions. These
little difficulties with human institutions made
no difference in the beauty of the scenery, but
I would not have you think that my adventures with the custom house ceased at this
point.
The journey from Como to Chiavenna can
be made by rail, but we did not propose to
travel in that manner, neither did we intend to
make the trip in the ordinary way by water,
but mounted our wheels, and started up the
western side of the western arm of the lake.
Lake Como would be better described by the
use of the word "leg," for on the map it looks
like an overgrown horse-raddish root on the
run, the city of Como being fastened to the
" toe of the forward foot. We followed the
road as far as the little town of Torriggia.
Here the highway suddenly dwindled to a
mule path, and we sat down under the trees to
rest, to photograph and sketch until the next
steamer came by. This arrived in the course
of an hour or two and we led our horses on
board. As we mounted the steps of the upper
deck we suddenly became conscious of friendly
faces. First one and then the other came forward, until there were four young men from
Baltimore before us. Not only that, but they
were all from my department of the University,
and persons with whom I had been in daily
association for years. You will excuse me if
I say this word "paralyzed" to express our
emotions, for at Bellaggio we changed the
steamer for a row boat and had ourselves propelled to the north side of the lake. From
that point we went up toward the passes of the
Alps by man power, furnished by members of
the party.
It was up in the pass above Chiavenna that
the closing events of this episode took place.

We had pushed rapidly up the hill in order to
reach the Swiss border at the proper time, and
full of haste and brown dust, I presented my
papers, receipts and passports. The official
was very polite. The papers were all clear
that I had deposited money, and that I was the
person. Very sorry, however, that he had no
authorization to /Say out money. Papers failed
to indicate at what point the bicycles were to
be exported. I had in fact told the people at
Chiasso a dozen times over that I was going
out by the way of Chiavenna, but they had
neglected the proper formalities. It would be
necessary to request the Italian government in
Rome to permit the custom house at Villa di
Chiavenna to return me the duty on two bicycles. The thing looked for a moment like robbery, but I was comforted with the assurance
that within two weeks the same thing had happened to eleven other Americans and that they
had come out all right.
It was Friday, and we were in the uttermost
parts of the kingdom. A petition by letter
meant a week or more of delay. So armed
with a properly worded telegram I hastened
back a mile down the hill to the shoemaker
who kept the post and telegraph office, and
turned over my affairs to the minions of electricity. In the meanwhile, we made ourselves
comfortable on the Swiss side of the line. It
was a village of at least seven houses, and in
the midst of chestnut trees, and side hill farming, performed by the female population. For
two whole days we studied Swiss institutions,
painted the scenery and collected botanical
specimens.
At five o'clock Saturday evening a reply,
dated at Rome at 12 the same day reached the
custom house at Villa di Chiavenna, and our
financial matters were straightened out.
I have never obtained a really satisfactory
history of that message. One does not like to
criticize unduly the methods of foreign governments when there may be great natural
difficulties to overcome. Especially is it true
in this case, where anyone can see from the
maps that Villa di Chianna is 2500 feet above
the sea, and the wire from Rome comes all the
way up hill.
JOHN MARTIN VINCENT.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
APELLO.
Mr. Editor.
It occured to me the other day that the great
use of a Junior in College is to advise Freshmen: and since I am debarred in future, from
giving Freshmen any more physical advice,
I am going to excercise my other prerogatives,
and give them some mental and moral advice
concerning a matter which I think should be
brought to their attention.
I wonder, to how many Freshman, has the
fact presented itself that they owe the University something more than their tuition fees?
You applaud the leaders of your class, the
members of the athletic teams, and,sometimes
the musical clubs. Do you ever try to do the
things they do? You cannot, you say. How
do you know you cannot? Have you tried?
If you are musical or shine in the social world,
join the musical clubs. If you are big and
strong, patronize "Mac" and the cage. If
you are studious, try for class honors. If you
are none of the above, but have a sneaking
fondness for Dr. Green's papers, try for the
NEWS-LETTER staff.
It is to this last class of men that I address
this appeal. It is your duty to help the paper,
because if you can write, your work is needed
in its columns. If the paper is not as good as
it might be (I am sure the editors will pardon
me) try and make it better. Criticism is good
but work is better. How can the editors ever
improve the NEWS-LETTER when everyone
abuses it, and no one writes for it? Don't be
like the basement-loafers who look at their
copies on alternate Thursday evenings, and
then always say "Well, it's a pretty bum
number. I don't see why we can't have a
good paper here." I asked one of these gentlemen one day if he had even done anything
to make it better, and he said "Oh, I sent in a
piece once, but they would'nt take it." I
discovered afterward that the piece in question
was something on the order of Baccaccio's
famous tales—naughty but very nice.
Now, boys, that is not the way to support
your college paper. The NEWS-LETTER represents the literary ability of the Hopkins undergraduate body. To the world at large we are

3

known by this paper. If we think it is poor,
we should make it better. If you think you
can write, try for the staff. If you don't make
it, write for the paper anyhow. If you have
,no literary ability, don't attempt to criticise
those who have. I know you are going to say
"Yes, that's true" and then do nothing. I did
the same thing. I am sorry now, and I am
doing penance by trying to keep you from my
error. There are places on the staff, fill them.
Show the rest of the world that the Hopkins
men are not all ignorant, and,show the rest of
the Hopkins men that the class of 1903 is alive to
its responsibilities. Don't wait 'till next year.
It will be too late then. Try now, and then
next year you will thank him who now gives
you this advice.

A JUNIOR.
GLORY BE UNTO HIM!
(Mr. W B. Swindell of the Senior class of the Johns Hopkins
University Is engaged to be married to a young lady of Boston,
Mass.—The Baltimore Sun.)

he's going to leave us! No longer
ALAS,
will his stentorian voice ring out in commanding tones urging a re-awakening of sleeping enthusiasts, no longer will the halls of
McCoy resound with his glorious voice, no
longer will the instructor in a political science
be compelled to outvoice the voice of him in
the holy corner. Yes he's going to leave us.
He who is the J. H. U., he who is everybody,
he who alone can command the bands of Hopkins, he—HE—HE is going to leave us. Weep,
ye legions weep. The attractions of the North
are too strong for this Southern son of valor,
he must go; even the baton of general is small
compared to the northern attraction. He has
laughed with us, he has fought with us, he has
lead us, he has spinached to us, and now he
will no longer give pleasure unto himself thus.
The future was bright before him. The
portals of a great institution were open to him.
Group III, with variations, lead anywhere: it
has lead to bliss for him. Happiness be with
him; and may he be blessed with many joys.
Success and glory be unto him who is

Athletic Editors,

(1

column of this issue we publish
IN"another
Billy" Maddren's letter of resignation
from his position as President of •the Athletic
Board. The "NEWS-LETTER" joins with the
student body in expressing its regret at the
loss from active leadership of one who has
been so conspicuous in athletic circles during
the past three years.
With the exception of Director Mackdermott, no one connected with the University is
more thoroughly alive to our athletic interests,
nor more completely conversant with every
branch of Hopkins sport than Mr. Maddren ;
while together with these qualities he combines
executive ability, and the faculty for imparting enthusiasm among the student ranks.
While Mr. Maddren has retired from his official position, we hope that we may still have
the benefit of his advice in athletic matters.
In choosing his successor we consider that
the Board has exercised great discernment.
Mr. Reese is one who has the athletic interests
of the University at heart, and anything he
undertakes is certain of a successful termination. Besides this he may rely upon the cooperation of the students.
or w
The successes of the Track and Field Team
in the recent indoor meets in this city and
Washington show plainly that despite our
heavy losses of last year Hopkins still has a
team which comes up to the high standard set

by the champions of 190o. Some of the best
men in the dashes and runs left the University,
but those remaining form a nucleus on which
at the beginning of this year Director Mackdermott started to build. The material in the
Freshman class was good, and under hard
training soon developed some excellent men in
the dashes, so that the first meet brought many
prizes to the trophy-room. The team has been
showing up stronger at every succeeding meet,
and deserves the heartiest congratulations of
all Hopkins men for its zealous efforts. Though
it is composed of men from all branches of the
University, there are enough younger men on
the team to assure a firm foundation for next
year.

In our last issue we called attention to the
duty now confronting us regarding the necessary improvements to be added to American
League Park, for the benefit of Hopkins Athletes. No matter what bright joys the future
holds in store for us, in the shape of expensive
athletic fields and green campuses, our present
needs are pressing. The musical :clubs have
generously enlisted themselves in the service
of raising the finances needed for this purpose,
and will shortly give a concert for tha benefit
of the athletic fund. It is gratifying to see
how the students have responded to the subscription call, and, judging from results thus
obtained, we predict that they can be counted
upon to turn out in a body the evening of the
concert. Despite our lack of students, our
athletic victories during the last few years
have placed Hopkins upon a higher footing in
the athletic world, and this fact together with
bright prospects for the future should stimulate
us all to greater activity.

and inwardly digest a communication in
these columns headed "Apello," and signed
"A Junior". The moral of the epistle is
pointed at the members of the Class of 1903,
but there is no reason why the rest of the
University should not profit by the excellent
advice contained therein. It is broad enough
to embrace all classes, but, doubtless the reason

THE NEWS-LETTER.
for especially admonishing the Freshmen is
because it is usually considered that their juvenile buoyancy is still in the effervescent
stage, and that their characters have not yet
been moulded into permanent form. In
by-gone days the "NEWS—LETTER" has harped
upon the theme of a man's duty to his college;
in days to come it will doubtless continue to sing
this lay, but a letter like "Apello" coming as
it does from one not officially connected with
this paper, carries with it more weight than
anything we may say upon the subject. Besides it is an encouraging sign, for it shows
that the work of "by gone days" is finally
bearing fruit.

A gratifying recognition of the worth of the
University has just been witnessed.
The German American citizens of Baltimore
propose to contribute $100,000 towards the
endowment fund of a million now being raised.
This contribution is to establish a chair of
German language and literature.
It is reported that $20,000 of the amount
has already been raised by fifteen gentlemen
who are members of the Germania Club. We
take pleasure in voicing the sentiment of gratitude which every Hopkins man must feel towards these liberal-minded gentlemen. Such
generosity should, and doubtless will,serve as
an object lesson to other beneficently inclined
citizens of Baltimore.

THE HOPKINS CLUB.
IT is reported that the Johns Hopkins Club
may soon move to other quarters. The growing attractiveness and interest would seem to
demand a site more easily reached by the
members. The Club boasts of an excellent
kitchen and buffet, which may be enjoyed at
very moderate rates; but the members do not
lunch or spend their evenings at the club as
much as they might, were the position nearer
the University, or on their way from places
of amusement. Great atttactions too are
offered to members who wish to occupy rooms
in the club house. It is felt that this and the
other good features of the Club will be enhanced by a more central location.

THE FRESHMAN BANQUET.
Freshman banquet, marking as it does
THE
the cessation of friendly clashes between
naughty two and naughty three, was a howling
Success from several standpoints. Almost every
member of the clsss attended, the apt speeches
were well delivered, and the presence of two
Juniors during the festivities added a certain
fascination to the pleasure, and without doubt,
made the affair the most unique in the annals
of similar feeds. The class of 1903 is the first
to enjoy the distinction of having entertained
such unheard of guests at its Freshmen banquet; and it is greatly to the credit of naughty
three that at no time during the evening was
a spirit of animosity exhibited. Songs were
sung, toasts were responded to, and frequent
knocks made at the Juniors, but at no time
were any attempts made to belittle or discomfort the unexpected guests. Before the last
course had been served the aforementioned
gentlemen were invited to partake of Freshman
hospitality. They accordingiy drew up, and
the mellowing influences of the spread soon
had their effects. Both guests made very appropriate speeches, and assured their entertainers that, with the exception of 1902, naughtythree is the best class that ever entered Hopkins. They ended by expressing sincere apapreciation for the hospitality accorded them.
As a toastmaster, Harry K. Tootle proved
to be the real thing. He was full of catchy
jokes, and always had some bright remark
to continue the merriment. His address in
which he referred to "taking the Law into
our hands" was greeted with deafening applause. The toast "Our Newly-Acquired
Possessions" was construed by some to refer
to the Juniors present, instead of Homewood.
Accordingly, some very good puns were gotten
off by impromptu speakers. The jolly time
ended with numerous class yells and songs,
interspersed with several rousing "Hullabaloos." The menu cards were bound in the
University colors with "class '03, J. H. U."
engraved in olive and white on the cover page.
Messrs. Robinson C. Pagon, Benjamin Weeks,
R. Curzon Hoffman, Wethered L. Lilly, and

MUSICAL CLUBS.
Johns Hopkins Glee, Banjo and ManHE
dolin Clubs gave an informal concert at
the University Club on the evening of Friday,
March Eighth. This is the first time that the
Clubs have appeared before the public in the
guise of a paid orchestra, and the result was
not altogether successful. The audience did
not deem it necessary to stop talking during
the songs and other pieces, consequently it
was hard for the men to play and sing, and
still harder for those who were appreciative to
hear the music. Altogether the evening was
not enjoyable or successful, and it is to be
hoped that no more such concerts will be
scheduled.
After a few attempts by the various Clubs
to make themselves heard, the men gave up,
and mingled with the crowd in its rush for
refreshments. Then the pleasanter part of the
evening began, for there were a number of
attractive girls and women present, and several
Johns Hopkins Professors and Alumni very
thoughtfully looked after the welfare of the
men.
Manager Bird has nearly completed his
arrangements for the Easter trip, and from
present prospects it will be as thoroughly successful as the one last year. So far the plans
are to leave Baltimore Friday afternoon ou one
of the Bay Line Steamers and give the first
concert at Old Point Comfort on Saturday
night. This is the very best night in the

whole year to attract an audience, and it was
only through the energy and perseverance of
the manager that this date was obtained. Last
year the Clubs had to play second best, and
give their concert on Good-Friday when there
were necessarily fewer people present. But
this year Princeton will have to take our last
year's place while the Hopkins Clubs have the
best night.
From Old Point Comfort the men will go to
Richmond and give a concert there on the following Monday—These places are the only
ones that are definitely decided upon, but it is
likely that several other cities will be visited
before the Clubs return. There is even a rumor that Atlantic City will be "taken in,"
but this is a little doubtful.

THE SECOND BALTIMORE CONCERT.
most important concert in the history
THE
of the Johns Hopkins Musical Clubs will
be given in McCoy Hall on Tuesday evening,
March 26. Its great importance lies in the
fact that the proceeds will be used to help pay
for the erection of the club house and gymnasium on the new athletic grounds.
The alumni of the University have been doing their utmost to raise the necessary million
dollar endowment fund, and it would surely
seem rather ungrateful in the undergraduates
if they do not heartily support this concert,
and thus take away the additional responsibility of paying for the club house.
From the manner in which the subscription
lists have been received, however, it is unlikely that the former Hopkins men will have any
reason to believe that they are the only ones
interested in the welfare of their Alma Mater.

"BILLY" MADDREN RESIGNS.

THE HOPKINS GAMES.

AT a meeting of the Athletic Board, held
Tuesday evening, March 12th, President
"Billy" Maddren handed in the 'following
letter of resignation:

Carnival of Sports under the auspices
THE
of the Athletic Association of the Johns

To the Board of Directors of the 7ohns Hopkins
Athletic Association:
GENTLEMEN,—It is with great regret that I
am obliged to tender my resignation as President of the Johns Hopkins Athletic Association. My reasons are that I am unable to
give sufficient time to athletic affairs because
of my studies. This resignation is to take
effect upon the election of my successor, and
not later than March i5th. Yours truly,
WILLIAM HARVEY MADDREN.
Every effort was used by the Board to dissuade Mr. Maddren from his course, but he
explained that it would be impossible for him
to devote sufficient time to the duties of presidency, as his studies at the Medical school for
the remainder of the year would require hard
work and close confinement. With great
reluctancy the board accepted the resignation,
and appointed a committee, with Dr. Renouf
as chairman, to draw up an appropriate resolution in appreciation of Mr. Maddren's work
in behalf of Hopkins Athletics. It is safe to
say, that during the past three years .no other
student of the University has instilled as much
life into athletics at Hopkins, as has "Billy
Maddren." His most conspicuous work has
been in Lacrosse, and it is largely owing to his
efforts that three championship banners, 1898,
1899, 1900, now adorn the walls of the trophy
room but besides this his advice in athletic
matters has been of the greatest benefit, and all
regret his retirement from active athletics.
Mr. Albert Reese was unanimously elected
by the Board to fill the position of president.
Mr, Reese is one of the few alumni who has
not allowed his interest in J. H. U. sports to
stop when he received his degree, but has, on
the other hand, worked faithfully to advance
them. This interest in athletics and his executive ability make him the most suitable man
who could have been chosen for the position.

Hopkins University was held on last Saturday night at the Fifth Regiment Armory.
Athletes from diverse parts of the city and
state were entertained by the University men,
who gave them a good run for their money.
These are the first indoor games that the
University has given for some years past, and
that they were a success is the verdict of everyone. Surely there were some hitches, but, for
the most part, the events were run off in good
time by the clerk of the course, Wm. M.
Mackdermott, to whom all credit is due for the
success of the meet.
The hall had been very attractively decorated, and when the call was sounded for the
first event at 8.10, the seats lining the walls
around the floor space of the Armory were
comfortably filled with fair enthusiasts who
had come out in goodly numbers to cheer their
especial favorites on to victory, while the gallery was filled with "rooters" of the various
organizations who had occupied themselves
with shouting encouragement to their teams.
A large share of the honors came to the
wearers of the Black and Blue, but the representatives of Marston's University School and
the Boys' Latin School also came in for a
goodly share of the prizes.
There was a slight delay in the starting of
the game owing to the late arrival of several
of the officials; but when the games were once
started they went ahead at a pleasing pace. The
program was a very attractive one, being much
less unwieldy than the ordinary program of
Baltimore meets. Foot races were the predominant features, while there were only three
field events.
The first event—the interscholastic 40 yard
dash—was easily won by G. C. Gantz, of the
Boys' Latin School, with Bayless and Cloud
close on him for second and third honors.
E. L. Pessagno ran a beautiful race in the
40 yard open handicap, winning first place, but
was closely pressed by Tootle, who won the
40 yard dash in the Baltimore Athletic games

THE NEWS-LETTER.

8

of several weeks ago. Perhaps the races which
interested the majority of the spectators were
the twelve relay races. In the first, Marston's
easily defeated the Emerson Institute team, of
Washington. The Boys' Latin School team
also ran a pretty race against Deichmann's.
The special invitation relay race between St.
John's College and Johns Hopkins University
was one of the prettiest of the evening. The
first two contestants, Whitman and Garey, ran
almost a dead heat till the last lap, when Whitman passed his rival and finished a few yards
ahead of him. Unfortunately for St. John's,
Wells was not able to hold his ground on the
next lap, and when Riggs took up the work
where England and Hoffman had left off,
Hopkins had a lead of half a lap, and Riggs
was able to hold his lead without exertion.
Mullen, who ran under the auspices of the
Johns Hopkins Club, was the only scratch man
in the mile run. He pushed ahead of all his
opponents, and caught up with Heiner, who
was leading. On the last lap Mullens purted,
and easily won by io yards.
In the 440 yard dash, Riggs ran a beautiful
race. On each lap he gradually pushed up
past his opponents, and won handily on the last
lap by a beautiful spurt. All the other events,
too, were of equal interest, but perhaps the
most amusing of the whole evening was the
potato race, won by C. F. Edwards. Garret
won first in the 16-lb. shot, and second in the
high jump. In the 88o yard, novice, England
was the victor.

BALL TEAM?

athletic department of the University
THE
of Chicago has started the policy of giving the University "C" to winners of indoor
meets,
ww
The candidates for Yale's track team are
showing up strong in the field events, but not
so well in the runs. There are 130 men in the
field.

SINCE"Robbie"and his small band of baseball enthusiasts have been practicing in the
cage here of late, considerable interest has
been shown in a base-ball team for Hopkins.
There seems to have been for some time past
a sort of half-hearted movement on foot to get
the consent of the Athletic Association for a
team. Such a movement will undoubtedly
meet with serious opposition, on account of the
deplorable manner in which last year's team
was managed, and its untimely end. Yet, if
the supporters of this new movement show
enough earnestness to warrant it, and will
guarantee a team which will practice, and stand
by the University during the entire season,
there can be no doubt but that the Athletic
Association will give such a team its hearty
support.
Several challenges have been received from
prominent colleges and associations, and it
seems rather sad, that we energetic Hopkinsonions who are making such rapid strides in
other lines of athletic sport, cannot organize
and support a base-ball team. Probably the
main handicap to last year's attempt was the
lack of grounds out of doors, on which to
practice. Such is not the case this year, as we
have new grounds specially adapted to baseball, at a moderate distance from the University.
If the men who are interested in this project
mean business, and have any hope of organizing a team, it is high time that the movement were being pushed as is is getting late in
the season. We have made a "rep for Hopkins in Football, Lacrosse, Track and Field.
Then with good material, and men who are
anxious and ready to make it a success, why
can we not have a base-ball team.

The course of lectures this year on the
Turnbull Lectureship foundation will be given
by Hamilton W. Mabie, Litt. D., editor of
"The Outlook," and author of several literary
works. The subject of the course will be
"Poetry in America." The lectures will be
given in McCoy Hall, at 5 o'clock, beginning
Tuesday, April 16th; they will begin punctually and will close within the hour. The door
will be closed when the lecturer rises.
Jab .a6
At their last monthly meeting, the Trustees
did not discuss the presidency of the University or the proposed endowment fund. A letter from Mr. Henry 0. Thompson, Treasurer
of the Alumni Association, presented the University p000 as the nucleus of a fund for the
establishment of an alumni scholarship. The
gift was accepted with thanks..
The trustees designated the professorship
founded some time ago by Dr. Henry Willis
Baxley as the Baxley Professorship of Pathology. They voted their thanks to Mr. Henry
Sonneborn and Mr. Jesse Tyson for recent
gifts to the University.

Dr. John Dewey, Hopkins Fellow in '83, and
Ph. D. '84, who is at present Professor of Philosophy in the University of Chicago, has been
appointed the head of the Chicago University
High School. This school is to be result of
the consolidation of the Chicago Institute with
the University of Chicago.

under the Constitution," will deliver four biographical lectures in continuation of his
course begun last year, on the great founders
of the American Republic. The lectures will
be given in the Donovan Room, McCoy Hall,
at 5 p. m., on March 20, 22, 27, and 30.

Columbia University, formerly Assistant Secretary of State and later Secretary to the Peace
Commission at Paris, will deliver two lectures
on international questions,—"Our Treaty with
Spain," and "Our Policy in the Far East."—
The lectures will be given in McCoy Hall, at
5 p. m., on March 19th and 21st.

The Senior—Junior debate is to take place
at 8 o'clock to-night in McCoy Hall.
The chairman of the committee of arrangements is Mr. Harry S. Bryne, who is president
of the Senate. Mr. A. W. Bruton will be chief
usher, Mr. Aubrey Pearre chairman of the
committee on invitations, and Mr. Norman
Boyer chairman of the press committee. The
arrangements committee has decided to limit
admission to the debate to those who have
tickets. These tickets may be obtained from
members of the Committee.
The Musical Clubs will take part in the exercises.
The Freshmen who will declaim for the Lee
prize at the same time, are Plaggemeyer, Blum,
and Zimmerman.

sweet. Also some special vintair.s of Deinhard & Co.'s celebrated Rhine
Wines selected while visiting thew great wine vaults at Coblenz on the
Rhine. The most valuable selection of all was the prize Oporto Port,
the finest of all Offley Forrester & Co.'s exhibit; a very old, strictly
